Explanation

Click OPEN ANSWER PDF to see the lines highlighted in green. These lines show you where the answer can be found.

This is a judgement (evaluation) type of question because you have to work out how the author has written the text. The clue is in the phrases 'like watery blood' and 'ominous, volcanic effect', while the guard was 'mystified'.

Tips for a judgement (evaluation) type of question

For some questions, you can find the answer in the text by reading and selecting sentences carefully and then making a judgement about the information provided, in order to work out the final answer.

For other questions, you will have to combine the facts that you read in the text with your own knowledge and observations, in order to work out the final answer.

This is a judgement (evaluation) type of question because you have to work out how the author has written the text and understand literary terms. 'Perched on silence' is a metaphor because it is not possible for a bird to perch on silence, as silence is not concrete.

Tips for a judgement (evaluation) type of question

For some questions, you can find the answer in the text by reading and selecting sentences carefully and then making a judgement about the information provided, in order to work out the final answer.

For other questions, you will have to combine the facts that you read in the text with your own knowledge and observations, in order to work out the final answer.

success.question_text: The words “flecked with autumn” refer to the

review_1.column_1_text:
Explanation

Click OPEN ANSWER PDF to see the line highlighted in green. This line shows you where the answer can be found.

This is an inferring (working out) type of question because you have to 'read between the lines' when you read part of the text. The clue is that the poet is describing the bird’s feathers. The comma indicates where the verb 'are' has been purposely left out. The poet uses this metaphor to imply the feathers (its plumage) are in autumn colours.

Tip for an inferring (working out) type of question

To find the answer you have to 'read between the lines' as this type of question is based on material that does not jump out and give you the answer straightaway. You need to know about material in the text and then combine it with your own knowledge and understanding to work out the final answer.

choice_1.label: season in which the bird died.

choice_3.label: time of year that the poet visited the museum.

choice_4.label: reason why the bird is no longer able to fly.

This is a general fact-finding type of question because you can find the fact in the text. Notice that the question is a 'What'-type question.

Tip for a general fact-finding type of question

You can find the answer because it's a fact in the text—so read the text carefully. Sometimes you will find the exact answer straightaway but other times you have to read a bit more carefully as the fact is hidden in the text.

Click OPEN ANSWER PDF to see the lines highlighted in green. These lines show you where the answer can be found.

This is an inferring (working out) type of question because you have to 'read between the lines' when you read part of the text. The clue is in the imagery used by the poet ('delicate bird' and 'snap-fine feet'), which suggests fragility.

Tip for an inferring (working out) type of question

To find the answer you have to 'read between the lines' as this type of question is based on material that does not jump out and give you the answer straightaway. You need to know about material in the text and then combine it with your own knowledge and understanding to work out the final answer.

success.question_text: Which of the following opinions would the poet most likely agree with?

review_1.column_1_text:
Explanation

Click OPEN ANSWER PDF to see the lines highlighted in green. These lines show you where the answer can be found.

This is a judgement (evaluation) type of question because you have to work out how the author has written the text. The clue is in the lines 'Better to see you ornament a distant sky / better to know you nourish the soil / with your brittle bones / than this'. The poet feels guilty that the dead bird, which still looks so lifelike, has been placed on display to be looked at rather than left to fulfil the natural cycle of life, decomposing in the earth when it died.

Tips for a judgement (evaluation) type of question

For some questions, you can find the answer in the text by reading and selecting sentences carefully and then making a judgement about the information provided, in order to work out the final answer.

For other questions, you will have to combine the facts that you read in the text with your own knowledge and observations, in order to work out the final answer.

choice_1.label: Natural history museums are no longer relevant.

choice_2.label: Animals should no longer be displayed in captivity.

choice_3.label: The natural cycle of nature should not be interfered with.

choice_4.label: People will not learn about nature from visiting museums.
